componenttext: Back half, all sort of middle of '11 and into back-to-school in '11. It seems to me that you have strong enough brands. And I've watched you pull the lever back on the promotions the last couple of weeks and months, suggesting that maybe there's a little more wiggle room for you guys and some other players out there.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, Marni, overall, I mean, we clearly have felt that we're getting better on how we execute some of those initiatives. We do have the benefit of the international mix coming into play more and more as we go forward. And I think if cost pressur
componenttext: Well, I think, Marni, overall, I mean, we clearly have felt that we're getting better on how we execute some of those initiatives. We do have the benefit of the international mix coming into play more and more as we go forward. And I think if cost pressures remain very significant then we're going to keep an open mind to pricing generally, although we certainly haven't made any decisions on that. But I think all of those factors -- we continue to look at.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: By the way, I misspoke, because we do promote in Canada, but that's treated by us as much as North America. But we don't promote internationally other than Canada.
componenttext: By the way, I misspoke, because we do promote in Canada, but that's treated by us as much as North America. But we don't promote internationally other than Canada.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Michelle Tan with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll go next to Michelle Tan with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jonathan, I was wondering if you could give us anymore color on how you think about the minimum cash cushion that you want to maintain as you look at buybacks going forward from here? Is there a $1 level per quarter or annually that you're thinking about?
componenttext: Jonathan, I was wondering if you could give us anymore color on how you think about the minimum cash cushion that you want to maintain as you look at buybacks going forward from here? Is there a $1 level per quarter or annually that you're thinking about?

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Michelle, I think there are sort of two guardrails in how we think about this. We're always going to want to maintain a healthy net cash cushion, which we define as our cash on hand less anything we've got drawn down on the revolver and any letters of cre
componenttext: Michelle, I think there are sort of two guardrails in how we think about this. We're always going to want to maintain a healthy net cash cushion, which we define as our cash on hand less anything we've got drawn down on the revolver and any letters of credit we have outstanding against the revolver. I think historically, we used to talk about a $300 million cash cushion. Going forward, I think we're thinking more in terms of a $350 million net cash cushion. So cash on hand less outstanding revolver draw downs and LCs that we would never want to be below around $350 million, is our current thinking. So that's, kind of, one guardrail. I think on the other end, we've seen our share count creep up over the last couple of years due to equity plan issuances. And I think going forward, we would, at the minimum, look to offset those equity plan share issuances with buybacks. So that, really, the kind of two guardrails. Where we end up between those two guardrails will be a function of how we're feeling about business, how we see our cash flow requirements in general going forward, market conditions, obviously, and potentially other factors. But we would expect to be somewhere within that range. So without the sort of floor being as of today, that we would never go below a $350 million net cash cushion, but isn't to say that we're going to be at that level. It's just that would be the sort of guardrail of the lower end.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Christine Chen with Needham & Company.
componenttext: We'll go next to Christine Chen with Needham & Company.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to piggyback off of the inventory question. Maybe another way to look at it, I mean, you are up against the down 30-something, but what's the breakout between other merchandise that has less fashion risk versus the fashion products? And how much
componenttext: I wanted to piggyback off of the inventory question. Maybe another way to look at it, I mean, you are up against the down 30-something, but what's the breakout between other merchandise that has less fashion risk versus the fashion products? And how much of that inventory is finished goods versus maybe work in process, i.e., the material that you might have bought that you can make into whatever you want to kind of mitigate the sourcing cost increases? And then if you could just talk about roll out of Gilly next year since it's doing so well?

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Christine, I guess on the inventory question. First of all, most of it is finished goods. There is the inventory in-transit component, which accounted for a percentage of the increase, but we stripped out inventory in-transit in the chart that's in the pr
componenttext: Christine, I guess on the inventory question. First of all, most of it is finished goods. There is the inventory in-transit component, which accounted for a percentage of the increase, but we stripped out inventory in-transit in the chart that's in the presentation. I think, as we said on the prior earnings call, we've never historically had issues with inventory, and we feel very comfortable about the inventory position we have. And we think we need the inventory levels we have to drive the business. So we're comfortable with where we are. And I think, in a historical context, the chart we have in the presentation illustrates that we are not really out of line with where we've historically been at this stage in the year.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: The second part of the question, Christine, I'll take rollout of Gilly. We're obviously very pleased with the results. We're very pleased with the 5,000 square foot store that we opened in Roseville, and we're going to see how we do in London on the 27th.
componenttext: The second part of the question, Christine, I'll take rollout of Gilly. We're obviously very pleased with the results. We're very pleased with the 5,000 square foot store that we opened in Roseville, and we're going to see how we do in London on the 27th. We're not in a position to make an announcement on anything other than that at this point. But thanks for the question.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Brian Tunick with JPMorgan.
componenttext: We'll go next to Brian Tunick with JPMorgan.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, are you guys reiterating your mid-single digit comp guidance for the fall season? And then as we try to get some more thoughts around the store closings for 2011, can you give us some idea whether it's occupancy or stores and distribution? What kin
componenttext: First, are you guys reiterating your mid-single digit comp guidance for the fall season? And then as we try to get some more thoughts around the store closings for 2011, can you give us some idea whether it's occupancy or stores and distribution? What kind of number can we expect to lower for next year based on the store closings?

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, Brian, on the first point, we had said -- I think what you're alluding to is we had said we'd pour to a mid-single digit comp for the full season. We haven't specifically updated that, but clearly our results for the third quarter were consistent
componenttext: I guess, Brian, on the first point, we had said -- I think what you're alluding to is we had said we'd pour to a mid-single digit comp for the full season. We haven't specifically updated that, but clearly our results for the third quarter were consistent with that buying assumption for the season, and we haven't spoke to anything subsequent to that. On store closings in '11, we'd originally said 110 over '10 and '11. Few of those are pulling forward into '10, but we'd still expect doing the 40 to 50 range in '11. The primary reason why those stores are unprofitable is low-volume, which does tend to result in very high, first of all, low growth margin rates. So closing those stores helps with the gross margin and then high occupancy costs as a percentage of sales in some cases although not all. So I think you're generally going to see -- I think, clearly, because we have to still staff them to minimum levels, those variable expense items tend to run as high percentage of sales. So I think you're going to see the impact on gross margin and then in both components of stores and distribution expenses from a leverage benefit. But also, keep in mind that we're talking about 67 or so stores this year, and then another sort of 40, 50 next year. And so you have to keep in that overall context.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Paul Lejuez with Nomura Securities.
componenttext: We'll go next to Paul Lejuez with Nomura Securities.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a couple more questions on the store closings. I know you haven't closed many yet this year, but I am wondering if you've looked to see if nearby stores are getting a bump from those stores closing? Also, how many of the stores are at lease expiratio
componenttext: Just a couple more questions on the store closings. I know you haven't closed many yet this year, but I am wondering if you've looked to see if nearby stores are getting a bump from those stores closing? Also, how many of the stores are at lease expiration? The ones that you plan to close this year? And then last, is there any near-term negative impact on the gross margin line in 4Q as you clear merchandise in closing those stores?

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Paul, I guess on the first question, it's something we will be looking at as we close these stores. But as you say, we've only closed a few so far. But we'll certainly be tracking what happens as we close the balance through the next couple of months to s
componenttext: Paul, I guess on the first question, it's something we will be looking at as we close these stores. But as you say, we've only closed a few so far. But we'll certainly be tracking what happens as we close the balance through the next couple of months to see what happens in terms of transferring business. And we'll also, by the way, be trying to do some things to help out the process as we close the stores. There will probably be some modest incremental markdowns associated with store closures but not particularly significant in the overall scheme. And the vast majority of the stores that are closing are by way of natural lease expirations this year, maybe not the vast majority but certainly the majority. There are a few buyouts and early closures included in the total.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010

componenttext: We'll go next to Robert Samuels with Phoenix Partners.

componenttext: Can you just elaborate a little bit more on the international Hollister stores? And what differences you're seeing, if any, by location and country?

componenttext: By location, the business is pretty uniformly strong. The one thing I can say that's interesting about our business is that I think, as many of you have noticed, more and more of our stores are requiring crowd control.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: One, I wanted to come back for a second just to the product cost issue. Because obviously, over the last year, you've been working really hard to get your average unit cost down. And I'm wondering if there is more room to go there? In other words, are the
componenttext: One, I wanted to come back for a second just to the product cost issue. Because obviously, over the last year, you've been working really hard to get your average unit cost down. And I'm wondering if there is more room to go there? In other words, are there certain things that will help you, in 2011, offset things like the increasing cotton prices and so forth?

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the answer to that, Dorothy, is you're very smart to know how hard we have worked at that. We will continue to do those things that will help us with AUC. And those things involve purchasing fabric for cross branding, things that don't involve tak
componenttext: I think the answer to that, Dorothy, is you're very smart to know how hard we have worked at that. We will continue to do those things that will help us with AUC. And those things involve purchasing fabric for cross branding, things that don't involve taking quality out of the product. We're, in fact, getting better at cross branding the fabric and bundling of like items. And we'll continue to do that, and that should give us benefits. But we do have headwind in terms of cotton and labor prices.

componenttext: And a follow on Hollister. Given the success in the European Community, has your vision for Hollister expanded beyond that community? And are there things that you've learned in Europe that can be brought to the United States?

componenttext: Richard, we are certainly looking at countries outside of Europe for future Hollister expansion. I think we'll increase, incrementally give more color on the specifics of that as we go forward. But certainly, we're looking beyond Europe, both for ANF and for Hollister.

componenttext: Just a question on the real estate. As you try to accelerate the Hollister openings in 2011 and 2012, can you talk a little about the availability in pricing of the deals that you're getting? And perhaps, how many leases you've secured for next year at this stage?

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jonathan, do you want to...
componenttext: Jonathan, do you want to...

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think with regard to specifics on number of stores next year, we'll be more clear on that coming into '11. We're still working through that as Mike alluded to earlier, putting a lot of effort to getting that closed down. So we'll be more specific
componenttext: Sure. I think with regard to specifics on number of stores next year, we'll be more clear on that coming into '11. We're still working through that as Mike alluded to earlier, putting a lot of effort to getting that closed down. So we'll be more specific on numbers of 2011 openings in February. In terms of rents, frankly, they vary significantly from country to country. They're certainly, in some like the U.K. or Germany, running significantly higher per square foot than they do domestically. But that makes sense given the much higher volumes we see. I think the key point for us is that when we open a store, we focus on that four wall margin and that we can generate sales volume that enables us to cover that rent and all the other expenses and still generate that four wall margin of 30% or hopefully better. And that's really the single critical factor that we focus on in each of these new deals.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your comments about the mid-single digit increase over the next two years. What are the components of that? Specifically, how do you expect average unit retail to trend over the next few quarters?
componenttext: Your comments about the mid-single digit increase over the next two years. What are the components of that? Specifically, how do you expect average unit retail to trend over the next few quarters?

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Linda, as we've said, we see domestic AURs to turning the corner, coming into 2011. The increasing international component of the business helped from a mix standpoint, as does the closures of underperforming high markdown domestic stores. I think,
componenttext: Well, Linda, as we've said, we see domestic AURs to turning the corner, coming into 2011. The increasing international component of the business helped from a mix standpoint, as does the closures of underperforming high markdown domestic stores. I think, beyond the first half of 2011, certainly, a component beyond that will be what we see continuing to happen on the cost front. But generally speaking, we expect to be in positive territory going forward on AURs and exactly how that plays out quarter-by-quarter. I think we'll see and give clearer guidance on as we go forward. But overall, in terms of getting to those mid-single digit comps, the premise is certainly that AURs has turned positive as opposed to continuing to climb.

componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about pricing you're seeing out of your competitors? And if, in fact, you're seeing competitive response to some of the more significant pricing actions that you've taken over the past couple of months?

componenttext: We don't really look at the business that way, Ed. We aggressively -- in driving our business. I can't really answer that question.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the only thing I would add is, or I would say is that the strongest correlation we see is how we plan our own business, not with what others are doing. And we saw that in the third quarter. I think we were extremely close to what we've planned for
componenttext: I think the only thing I would add is, or I would say is that the strongest correlation we see is how we plan our own business, not with what others are doing. And we saw that in the third quarter. I think we were extremely close to what we've planned for the business in terms of comps in particular. And that I think we feel more and more comfortable going forward about our ability to have clear visibility on the trend of the business. And what we are planning is the single most important determinant of how we end each quarter.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010

componenttext: We'll go next to Roxanne Meyer with UBS.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: When you mentioned your long-term gross margin goal of 67%, can you tell us what that assumes about where the U.S. business can get to over time? And then separately, can you just remind us if there's any average unit costing opportunities still in the fo
componenttext: When you mentioned your long-term gross margin goal of 67%, can you tell us what that assumes about where the U.S. business can get to over time? And then separately, can you just remind us if there's any average unit costing opportunities still in the fourth quarter?

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess on the second part, there is -- we continue to get average unit cost benefit in the fourth quarter year-over-year. It's a little less than the third quarter, which was less than the spring. So year-over-year, it's abating as we go through the year
componenttext: I guess on the second part, there is -- we continue to get average unit cost benefit in the fourth quarter year-over-year. It's a little less than the third quarter, which was less than the spring. So year-over-year, it's abating as we go through the year. In terms of the long-term gross margin goal, to be at that level, and in general, to be back at that 15% operating margin level, domestic margins would be south of 15%, with international margins being a good bit north of that. So we would not be back at that historic peaks for the Domestic business by any means to be back of that overall 15% operating margin goal.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Jennifer Black with Jennifer Black and Associates.
componenttext: We'll go next to Jennifer Black with Jennifer Black and Associates.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your accessories look great, and it looks like you've increased the penetration, especially at the Abercrombie division. And I wondered if that's the case, what are your thoughts about it going forward? And then within accessories, can you talk a little b
componenttext: Your accessories look great, and it looks like you've increased the penetration, especially at the Abercrombie division. And I wondered if that's the case, what are your thoughts about it going forward? And then within accessories, can you talk a little bit about the Fragrance business? I know that's a really big opportunity for you.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: The Fragrance business does offer us huge opportunity. As we've said, Fierce is currently, this year, I think going to be an $88 million business, and we don't have a female equivalent. So if we could just come up with that, we'd have a lot of business. R
componenttext: The Fragrance business does offer us huge opportunity. As we've said, Fierce is currently, this year, I think going to be an $88 million business, and we don't have a female equivalent. So if we could just come up with that, we'd have a lot of business. Regarding the rest of accessories, we're pushing. We're seeing success in male and female accessories as of this moment. But we have a long way to go.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to David Glick with Buckingham Research.
componenttext: We'll go next to David Glick with Buckingham Research.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on Gilly Hicks. I know that it's premature to talk about the extent of the opportunity. But I was just curious, Mike, how you look at the U.S. versus Europe? Clearly, U.S., potentially a bigger market, their competitive landscape seems a
componenttext: Just a follow-up on Gilly Hicks. I know that it's premature to talk about the extent of the opportunity. But I was just curious, Mike, how you look at the U.S. versus Europe? Clearly, U.S., potentially a bigger market, their competitive landscape seems a little more devoid of competition in Europe, and wondering if you see that as, perhaps, a faster rollout in that region versus the U.S.?

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: David, I don't really -- no. We haven't opened a European store. We will at the end of this month. It is possible that Gilly has the same potential as Hollister in terms of worldwide locations, but we're taking it very easy, and we're looking at it in a v
componenttext: David, I don't really -- no. We haven't opened a European store. We will at the end of this month. It is possible that Gilly has the same potential as Hollister in terms of worldwide locations, but we're taking it very easy, and we're looking at it in a very hard way.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Robin Murchison with SunTrust.
componenttext: We'll go next to Robin Murchison with SunTrust.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you could just remind me please of this year, air versus ocean? And if you expect it to remain the same for the out year, for next year?
componenttext: If you could just remind me please of this year, air versus ocean? And if you expect it to remain the same for the out year, for next year?

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Air versus ocean has been down. We've been boating much more this year than we historically did. I'm not sure we've given specific percentages, but it's a relatively low percentage that's now coming in by air. And that's one of the factors that's driven t
componenttext: Air versus ocean has been down. We've been boating much more this year than we historically did. I'm not sure we've given specific percentages, but it's a relatively low percentage that's now coming in by air. And that's one of the factors that's driven that increase in inventory in-transit. I think going forward, given where air rates are at, we'll be looking to stay close to that. It took to the current mix, there will always be some air, but we are seeking to continue to have most goods coming in by boat.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Stacy Pak with SP Research.
componenttext: We'll go next to Stacy Pak with SP Research.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you just follow-up on the Q4 gross margin guidance? I'm trying to understand, if I look at your comparisons, specially going back to '08 versus Q3, it looks an awful lot easier. And your AUR was really nicely flat in October. So I'm still struggling t
componenttext: Can you just follow-up on the Q4 gross margin guidance? I'm trying to understand, if I look at your comparisons, specially going back to '08 versus Q3, it looks an awful lot easier. And your AUR was really nicely flat in October. So I'm still struggling to understand why the gross margin should be down equivalent to Q3? And am I right? Your guidance is basically implying the Street needs to come down about $0.08, am I on the line there?

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly no. What we're saying specifically, I mean, I think everyone has their different models. A couple of points there, Stacy. Firstly, average unit costs, as I said a second ago, is moderating in terms of year-over-year benefit we’re getting
componenttext: Well, certainly no. What we're saying specifically, I mean, I think everyone has their different models. A couple of points there, Stacy. Firstly, average unit costs, as I said a second ago, is moderating in terms of year-over-year benefit we’re getting in the fourth quarter. So we do expect year-over-year AUR declines to also moderate. The two things are moderating together. And I think, as we've said in the past, you can't read too much into one month. So October AUR was pretty much flat, but we are not saying that any given month is indicative of what we're going to be seeing for the balance of the season. So we do expect AURs to continue to be down in the fourth quarter. And the reason why the gross margin is roughly equivalent is because the AUC is -- the benefit we're getting year-over-year is less than it was a year ago, as well as a couple of other minor factors year-over-year and some of the other gross margin components.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Adrienne Tennant with Janney Capital Markets
componenttext: We'll go next to Adrienne Tennant with Janney Capital Markets

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: My first question, Mike, is for you really. You did touch on the fact that the stores in Europe and Asia sort of performed similarly? Can you talk about the customer buying behavior? And the success that you've had in Japan, does that sort of open the doo
componenttext: My first question, Mike, is for you really. You did touch on the fact that the stores in Europe and Asia sort of performed similarly? Can you talk about the customer buying behavior? And the success that you've had in Japan, does that sort of open the door for you to go into China? What would need to happen to sort of move into China and Hong Kong?

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: First answer is that our stores respond very much the same around the world. We sell the same product, we offer the same environment, experience, all of what we bring to the retail experience. I think the difference is there's just a different level of vo
componenttext: First answer is that our stores respond very much the same around the world. We sell the same product, we offer the same environment, experience, all of what we bring to the retail experience. I think the difference is there's just a different level of volume. So we offer the same experience in the U.S. as Europe, we just are doing more business on a store-by-store basis in Europe, on an average store basis in Europe than we are in the U.S. today. But the product breakdown, in terms of what we sell by store, the percentage is basically the same. The second part of your question, what would it take for us to announce that we're going to China, I think Jonathan has said, we are making no announcements at this point. But we have a very strong belief that what is happening in Hollister and around the world can be duplicated in many places.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Linda McDonough with Waterloo Advisors.
componenttext: We'll go next to Linda McDonough with Waterloo Advisors.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wondered if you could quantify the FX impact in the quarter and also the lower depreciation that you had mentioned?
componenttext: I wondered if you could quantify the FX impact in the quarter and also the lower depreciation that you had mentioned?

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Linda, the FX impact year-over-year for the quarter was slightly negative. I think less than 1% of sales, adverse effect year-over-year. It was slightly better than we had budgeted based on where the rates moved from the beginning of the quarter. And the
componenttext: Linda, the FX impact year-over-year for the quarter was slightly negative. I think less than 1% of sales, adverse effect year-over-year. It was slightly better than we had budgeted based on where the rates moved from the beginning of the quarter. And the second part of the question was lower depreciation. There was some assets that we thought would potentially go out of service during the quarter, which didn't, and that was the primary reason for that reduction.

headline: Abercrombie & Fitch Co., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: That does conclude today's conference. Thank you for everyone for your participation.
componenttext: That does conclude today's conference. Thank you for everyone for your participation.
